cards.title: Five days of art and music in Israel / Midburn festival in the Negev desert
cards.rawTitle: Midburn festival in the Negev desert

item.title: Midburn festival in the Negev desert
item.trailText: Israel’s version of Nevada’s Burning Man festival concluded on Sunday in the Negev desert. In keeping with the Burning Man tradition, thousands of revellers pitched tents in the desert for five days of art, dance and music, before choosing to burn their exhibits on the last two nights of the festival
item.standFirst: Israel’s version of Nevada’s Burning Man festival concluded on Sunday in the Negev desert. In keeping with the Burning Man tradition, thousands of revellers pitched tents in the desert for five days of art, dance and music, before choosing to burn their exhibits on the last two nights of the festival

displayImages.caption: Now in its second year, the organisers of Midburn seek to create a ‘platform which will allow a communal life style, creativity, art and radical self-expression’ Photograph: Amir Cohen/Reuters
displayImages.altText: Now in its second year, the organisers of Midburn seek to create a ‘platform which will allow a communal life style, creativity, art and radical self-expression’.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Now in its second year, the organisers of Midburn seek to create a ‘platform which will allow a communal life style, creativity, art and radical self-expression’

displayImages.caption: Some 6,000 festivalgoers attended the festival in 2015, transforming the arid desert in southern Israel to an oasis of creativity Photograph: Abir Sultan/EPA
displayImages.altText: Some 6,000 festivalgoers attended the festival in 2015, transforming the arid desert in southern Israel to an oasis of creativity.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Some 6,000 festivalgoers attended the festival in 2015, transforming the arid desert in southern Israel to an oasis of creativity

displayImages.caption: Like its US counterpart, the Midburn festival ‘welcomes and respects the stranger’, and has a core principle of gift giving and radical self-expression Photograph: Abir Sultan/EPA
displayImages.altText: Festival goers in costume walking during the Israel Midburn festival in the Negev desert southern Israel
displayImages.cleanCaption: Like its US counterpart, the Midburn festival ‘welcomes and respects the stranger’, and has a core principle of gift giving and radical self-expression

displayImages.caption: The first Midburn took place in 2014, after about two years of planning. The festival’s 2014 population was 3,000 – meaning the 2015 event was double the size Photograph: Amir Cohen/Reuters
displayImages.altText: The first Midburn took place in 2014, after about two years of planning
displayImages.cleanCaption: The first Midburn took place in 2014, after about two years of planning. The festival’s 2014 population was 3,000 – meaning the 2015 event was double the size

displayImages.caption: A festivalgoer pauses during the festival to look through a telescope to survey the sweeping Negev desert landscape Photograph: Abir Sultan/EPA
displayImages.altText: A festivalgoer pauses during the festival to look through a telescope to survey the sweeping Negev desert landscape
displayImages.cleanCaption: A festivalgoer pauses during the festival to look through a telescope to survey the sweeping Negev desert landscape

displayImages.caption: Intimacy beneath the flags: nothing can be bought or sold at Midburn, including food and beverages. The festival city is intended to be a place of sharing and free exchange within a gifting economy Photograph: Menahem Kahana/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Intimacy beneath the flags: nothing can be bought or sold at Midburn, including food and beverages. The festival city is intended to be a place of sharing and free exchange within a gifting economy.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Intimacy beneath the flags: nothing can be bought or sold at Midburn, including food and beverages. The festival city is intended to be a place of sharing and free exchange within a gifting economy

displayImages.caption: People dance during the Midburn festival at southern Israel. Water is not provided at the event, and festivalgoers are advised to bring five litres of water for each day they are at the desert camp Photograph: Amir Cohen/Reuters
displayImages.altText: People dance during the Midburn festival at southern Israel. Water is not provided at the event, and festivalgoers are advised to bring five litres of water for each day they are at the desert camp.
displayImages.cleanCaption: People dance during the Midburn festival at southern Israel. Water is not provided at the event, and festivalgoers are advised to bring five litres of water for each day they are at the desert camp

displayImages.caption: Midburn is a portmanteau of the Hebrew world for desert and the English word ‘burn’, in reference to the Burning Man festival in Nevada Photograph: Abir Sultan/EPA
displayImages.altText: Midburn is a portmanteau of the Hebrew world for desert and the English word ‘burn’, in reference to the Burning Man festival in Nevada.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Midburn is a portmanteau of the Hebrew world for desert and the English word ‘burn’, in reference to the Burning Man festival in Nevada

displayImages.caption: Israeli body artists embrace at dusk: the 2015 Midburn theme was transcendence, which the organisers described as ‘reaching the boundaries of one’s self and beyond the personal point of perception’ Photograph: Abir Sultan/EPA
displayImages.altText: Israeli body artists embrace at dusk: the 2015 Midburn theme was transcendence, which the organisers described as ‘reaching the boundaries of one’s self and beyond the personal point of perception’.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Israeli body artists embrace at dusk: the 2015 Midburn theme was transcendence, which the organisers described as ‘reaching the boundaries of one’s self and beyond the personal point of perception’

displayImages.caption: Statues, art exhibits, performances, theme camps, art-cars and costumes blossom within the social space created by the Midburn organisers Photograph: Amir Cohen/Reuters
displayImages.altText: Statues, art exhibits, performances, theme camps, art-cars and costumes blossom within the social space created by the Midburn organisers.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Statues, art exhibits, performances, theme camps, art-cars and costumes blossom within the social space created by the Midburn organisers

displayImages.caption: A couple dressed in costumes sit inside a hut during the festival, which takes place near the Israeli kibbutz of Sde Boker Photograph: Menahem Kahana/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: A couple dressed in costumes sit inside a hut during the festival, which takes place near the Israeli kibbutz of Sde Boker.
displayImages.cleanCaption: A couple dressed in costumes sit inside a hut during the festival, which takes place near the Israeli kibbutz of Sde Boker

displayImages.caption: No sleep for free souls: the Midburn festival comes alive during the night as attendees play with lights during performance art presentations and dance parties Photograph: Abir Sultan/EPA
displayImages.altText: No sleep for free souls: the Midburn festival comes alive during the night as attendees play with lights during performance art presentations and dance parties.

cards.title: The people of the Omo Valley
cards.rawTitle: The people of the Omo Valley

item.title: The people of the Omo Valley
item.trailText: The people of the Omo Valley are incredibly photogenic. But tourism is turning their lives into a daily fancy dress parade.
item.standFirst: The people of the Omo Valley are incredibly photogenic. But tourism is turning their lives into a daily fancy dress parade. Photographer and writer Matilda Temperley, feeling partly responsible, decided to chart their transformation

displayImages.caption: A Suri woman wearing her traditional wooden lip-plate.
displayImages.altText: A Suri woman wearing her traditional wooden lip-plate.

cards.title: Female activists cross demilitarised zone between North and South Korea
cards.rawTitle: Female activists cross demilitarised zone between North and South Korea

item.title: Female activists cross demilitarised zone between North and South Korea
item.trailText: A group of peace activists from around the world, led by US feminist writer Gloria Steinem, made a rare crossing of one of the world's most militarised borders on Sunday
item.standFirst: A group of peace activists from around the world, led by US feminist writer Gloria Steinem, made a rare crossing of one of the world's most militarised borders on Sunday. The group briefly entered part of the border between North and South Korea, with Steinem saying they acted as 'citizen diplomats'

cards.title: Tree cutting competition held in Estonia
cards.rawTitle: Tree cutting competition held in Estonia

item.title: Tree cutting competition held in Estonia
item.trailText: Students from various forestry colleges across Europe take part in the 14th European Championship of Forestry Skills in Luua, Estonia between 20-24 May
item.standFirst: Students from various forestry colleges across Europe take part in the 14th European Championship of Forestry Skills in Luua, Estonia between 20-24 May. The competitors were tested on a range of skills, as well as their speed with a chainsaw. The overall winner this year was Julian Schwender of Germany, with Ranet Sildoja of Estonia second and Guzevicius Tadas of Lithuania

cards.title: Australia / World motorised cooler championships held

item.title: World motorised cooler championships held in Australia
item.trailText: The world's first motorised cooler championships are held in Port Douglas, Australia on Sunday
item.standFirst: The world's first motorised cooler championships are held in Port Douglas, Australia, on Sunday. The event was a part of Port Douglas' Carnivale celebrations, attracting competitors from across the world to race around a 105-metre uneven grass track. The motor coolers, available across Australia and New Zealand, had a top speed of 20kmph (12mph) and drivers tested their skills around tight hairpin bends in what organisers called a quintessentially Australian event

stillImage.caption: 620x372 trailpic for World Motorised Cooler Championships held in Australia - vide Photograph: guardian.co.uk
stillImage.altText: 620x372 trailpic for World Motorised Cooler Championships held in Australia - vide

cards.title: The very best … / Vintage circus posters

item.title: Vintage circus posters
item.trailText: Jaap Best devoted his life to collecting vintage circus posters. From creepy clowns to performing cats, here are the best of them
item.standFirst: Creepy clowns, flying acrobats, performing cats: circuses were big business at the turn of the 20th century. Dutch circus lover Jaap Best devoted his life to collecting vintage posters from across Europe. After he died in 2002, the Jaap Best Circus Archive Foundation bequeathed his 8,000 posters to the Teylers Museum in Haarlem, which put them on an online database (www.circusmuseum.nl/eng/). Foundation board member Herman Voogd says: “These are historic documents. You can think what you like about it, but the old style of circus is disappearing: in many places they don’t allow live animal shows any more. But these lithographs are so beautifully designed – they were all originally hand-painted – and now everyone can enjoy them.”

displayImages.altText: Tiger - Circus Willy Hagenbeck
Magician - Seance mysterieuse. Prof Bourdini, Printer Adolph Friedl
Horses - Circus Mikkenie, Printer Orcel

Acrobat Family - Kremo-Familie, Les papillon d'or, Artist William Rohde
